course1.prereq: 3521 or 5521, and 2501 or Phil 1338, and CSE 3901 or 3902 or 3903, and 2nd writing; or grad standing.
course1.name: Capstone Design: Knowledge-Based Systems
course1.desc: Capstone design project; conceptual and technical design; theory and practice of knowledge-based systems; teamwork, written and oral communication skills.

course2.prereq: 3231 or 5231, and 2501 or Philos 1338, and CSE3901 or 3902 or 3903, and 2nd writing course or grad standing.
course2.topic: SWE methodology selection, High-level project, teamwork
course2.name: Capstone Design: Software Applications
course2.desc: Capstone design project: application of software engineering techniques, methodologies and technologies in software lifecycle activities using enterprise software frameworks; teamwork, written and oral communication.

course3.prereq: 3541 or 5541, and 2501 or Philos 1338, and CSE 3901 or 3902 or 3903, and second writing course; or Grad standing.
course3.topic: SWE for games, game idea generation, High-level project
course3.name: Capstone Design: Game Design and Development
course3.desc: Capstone design project; conceptual and technical design and implementation of interactive game, integrating custom code and toolkits; teamwork, written and oral communication skills.

course4.prereq: 3541 or 5541, and 2501 or Philos 1338, and CSE 3901 or 3902 or 3903, and second writing course; or Grad standing
course4.name: Capstone Design: Computer Animation
course4.desc: Capstone design project: conceptual and technical design and implementation of computer animation incorporating animation elements; teamwork, written and oral communication skills.

course5.prereq: 3241 or 5241, and 2501 or Philos 1338, and CSE 3901 or 3902 or 3903, and second writing course; or Grad standing
course5.topic: Web-based Information Systems, multimedia and scientific data management
course5.name: Capstone Design: Information Systems
course5.desc: Capstone design project; information system principles: database design methods and tools, indexing, searching, application development, testing, evaluation; teamwork, written and oral communication skills.

course6.prereq: 2501 or Philos 1338, and CSE 3901 or 3902 or 3903, and second writing course; or Grad standing
course6.topic: The scientific method, theory-guided data science, the data science life-cycle,  data analysis
course6.name: Capstone Design: Research-Focused Projects
course6.desc: Capstone design project; convergent and scalable research formulation and development, computational solutions to open-ended research problems, teamwork, written and oral communication skills.

course7.prereq: 2331 or 5331, or Grad standing. Not open to students with credit for 3521
course7.name: Survey of Artificial Intelligence I: Basic Techniques
course7.desc: Survey of the basic concepts and techniques in artificial Intelligence, including problem solving, knowledge representation, and machine learning.

course8.prereq: 3521 or 5521, and enrollment in CSE, CIS, ECE, or Data Analytics major; or Grad standing.
course8.topic: Probability theory, Bayesian networks and probabilistic representations, Machine learning, Natural language processing, Diagrammatic reasoning and abductive inference, Computer vision
course8.name: Survey of Artificial Intelligence II: Advanced Techniques
course8.desc: Survey of advanced concepts, techniques, and applications of artificial intelligence, including knowledge representation, learning, natural language understanding, and vision.

course9.prereq: 3521, 5521, or 5243; and 5522, Stat 3460, or 3470; and Math 2568, 2174, 4568, or 5520H; or Grad standing.
course9.topic: Basics of statistical pattern recognition, Probability and statistical inference, Bayes decision theory, Analysis of statistical algorithms, Clustering, Spectral clustering
course9.name: Machine Learning and Statistical Pattern Recognition
course9.desc: Introduction to basic concepts of machine learning and statistical pattern recognition; techniques for classification, clustering and data representation and their theoretical analysis.

course10.prereq: 2331, or Sr or Grad standing. Not open to students with credit for 634.
course10.topic: Introductory computer vision, Image formation, Noise removal, Edge detection, Pyramids, Region segmentation, 2-D shape, Template matching, Motion, Tracking, 3-D, Event analysis, Features, Motion capture
course10.name: Computer Vision for Human-Computer Interaction
course10.desc: Computer vision algorithms for use in human-computer interactive systems; image formation, image features, segmentation, shape analysis, object tracking, motion calculation, and applications.

course11.prereq: (CSE 3521 or CSE 5521) and (CSE 5522 or Stat 3460 or Stat 3470)
course11.name: Foundations of Speech and Language Processing
course11.desc: Fundamentals of natural language processing, automatic speech recognition and speech synthesis; lab projects concentrating on building systems to process written and/or spoken language.

course12.prereq: 3521 or 5521. Not open to students with credit for 779
course12.topic: Introduction and McCulloch-Pitts networks, Perceptrons, Regression and least mean square algorithm, Multilayer perceptrons, Radial-basis function networks, Support vector machines, Recurrent networks, Unsupervised learning and self-organization,
course12.name: Introduction to Neural Networks
course12.desc: Survey of fundamental methods and techniques of neural networks; single- and multi-layer perceptrons; radial-basis function networks; support vector machines; recurrent networks; supervised and unsupervised learning.

course13.prereq: 2421, or 2451 and ECE 2560; and enrollment in CSE, CIS, Data Analytics, or ECE majors.
course13.name: Systems II: Introduction to Operating Systems
course13.desc: Introduction to operating system concepts: process, CPU scheduling, memory management, file system and storage, and multi-threaded programming.

course14.prereq: 1212, 1221, 1222, 1223, 1224, Engr 1221, 1281.01H, 1281.02H, or CSE Placement Level A. Prereq or concur: Math 1151, 1161.01, or 1161.02. Not open to students with credit for 5022.
course14.name: Software I: Software Components
course14.desc: Intellectual foundations of software engineering; design-by-contract principles; mathematical modeling of software functionality; component-based software from client perspective; layered data representation

course15.prereq: Prereq: 2221. Concur: 2321. Not open to students with credit for 2231.01.
course15.name: Software II: Software Development and Design
course15.desc: Data representation using hashing, search trees, and linked data structures; algorithms for sorting; using trees for language processing; component interface design; best practices in Java.

course16.prereq: 2122, 2123 or 2231; and 2321 or Math 2566; and enrollment in CSE, CIS, Data Analytics or Math majors
course16.name: Systems I: Introduction to Low-Level Programming and computer Organization
course16.desc: Introduction to computer architecture at machine and assembly language level; pointers and addressing; C programming at machine level; computer organization

course17.prereq: Prereq: 2122, 2123, or 2221; and Math 1151, or 1161. Concur (for students with credit for 2221): 2231.
course17.name: Foundations I: Discrete Structures
course17.desc: Propositional and first-order logic; basic proof techniques; graphs, trees; analysis of algorithms; asymptotic analysis; recurrence relations.

course18.prereq: Prereq: 2231, 2321, and Stat 3460 or 3470. Concur: Math 3345 and enrollment in CSE, CIS, ECE, Data Analytics, Math majors or CIS minor.
course18.name: Foundations II: Data Structures and Algorithms
course18.desc: Design/analysis of algorithms and data structures; divide-and-conquer; sorting and selection, search trees, hashing, graph algorithms, string matching; probabilistic analysis; randomized algorithms; NP-completeness.

course19.prereq: Not open to students with credit for 1111 or 1113
course19.topic: Computers in society; word processing, Application software, The components of the system unit; spreadsheet application, Operating systems and utility programs, input and output devices, Database management; communications and networks
course19.name: Introduction to Computing Technology
course19.desc: A course of general interest giving experience with personal computer software, e.g., word processors and spreadsheets; provides fundamental computer literacy; neither teaches nor requires programming.

course20.prereq: Not open to students with credit for 1112 (105), 1113 (101), or 200. GE quant reason math and logical anly course
course20.name: Introduction to Computer-Assisted Problem Solving
course20.desc: Problem solving techniques using productivity software; spreadsheets, formulas, conditional logic; relational databases, relational algebra; word processing; data presentation; graphics.

course21.prereq: Not open to students with credit for 1111 (101), 1113, 105, or 200.
course21.topic: Computer basics, Excel, simple webpage, powerpoint
course21.name: Introduction to Computer-Assisted Problem Solving for Construction Systems Management
course21.desc: Using productivity software, especially spreadsheets and databases, to solve problems for construction management; relative/absolute cell referencing, logic, functions; relational databases, querying, project integration.

course22.prereq: Math 1130 (130) or above. Not open to students with credit for 1111 (101), 1112 (105), 2111, or 200.
course22.name: Spreadsheet Programming for Business
course22.desc: Spreadsheet modeling/programming concepts and techniques to solve business related problems; efficient/effective data handling, computational analysis and decision support.

course23.prereq: Not open to students with credit for 1111, 1112, or 2111.
course23.topic: Relational database management systems, Table Relationships, Use the query tool to find/organize information, Access Macros, SQL, Forms and Reports
course23.name: Introduction to Databases Using MS Access
course23.desc: Database concepts and techniques for efficient/effective data handling, computational analysis and decision support.

course24.prereq: Not open to students with credit for 203 or 204.
course24.topic: Software installation, and basic concepts, intro to programming with media, images, colors, encodings, Loops, new definitions, simple image manipulations, Nested loops, conditionals, Boolean expressions, advanced image manipulations, Sequencing, iteration, and drawing,
course24.name: Computational Thinking in Context: Images, Animation, and Games
course24.desc: Introduction to computational thinking, focusing on problem solving and programming concepts and skills needed to manipulate digital images and to create interactive graphics, animations, and games; creativity and imagination encouraged.

course25.topic: Basic concepts of video games, Introduction to programming for web-based games, Loops, new definitions, simple controls, Conditionals, Boolean expressions, advanced controls
course25.name: Computational Thinking in Context: Game Development
course25.desc: Introduction to computational thinking, focusing on problem solving and programming concepts and skills needed to develop video games.

course26.prereq: Concur:Math 1151, 1154, or 1161. Not open to students with credit for Engr 1281.01 or 1281.02. This course is available for EM credit.
course26.topic: C++, loop, method, pointer, structure, c++ array, c++ string
course26.name: Introduction to Computer Programming in C++ for Engineers and Scientists
course26.desc: Introduction to computer programming and to problem solving techniques using computer programs with applications in engineering and the physical sciences; algorithm development; programming lab experience.

course27.prereq: Math 1130, 1140, 1149, 1150, or 1151, or Math Placement Level L. This course is available for EM credit.
course27.topic: Basic concepts, Primitive types and expressions; String; basic I/O, Flow of control and Boolean expressions, Defining methods, Arrays, Basic exception handling and standard Java I/O, Classes and objects
course27.name: Introduction to Computer Programming in Java
course27.desc: Introduction to computer programming and to problem solving techniques using computer programs; programming lab experience.

course28.prereq: Math 1130, 1140, 1149, 1150, or 1151, or Math Placement Level L.
course28.topic: Expressions and Types; basic I/O, Lists, Tuples and Dictionaries, Flow of control and Boolean expressions, Defining functions, File I/O, Classes and objects
course28.name: Introduction to Computer Programming in Python
course28.desc: Introduction to computer programming and to problem solving techniques using computer programs; programming lab experience.
